Přiklopil allegedly had a daughter with the sister of a business partner.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2303168/Natascha-Kampuschs-father-names-second-kidnapper-claims-police-covered-errors-search-daughter-explosive-new-book.html|title=Natascha Kampusch's father names a second kidnapper and claims police covered up errors in the search for his daughter in explosive new book|author=Allan Hall|date=3 April 2013|work=Daily Mail|location=London}}</ref>
Before Kampusch escaped, Přiklopil was trying to procure false papers as a Czech citizen, in order to "begin a new life" with Kampusch.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/crooked-nose-drove-kampusch-kidnapper-claims-his-best-friend-2044822.html Crooked nose drove Kampusch kidnapper claims his best friend], The Independent</ref>
{{Clear}}
== After the escape == In her official statement Kampusch said "I don't want and will not answer any questions about personal or intimate details".<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/5293198.stm | title= Text: Austria kidnap girl's statement | work= | publisher= [[BBC News Online]] | pages= | page= | date= 28 August 2006 | accessdate= 30 August 2006 }}</ref> After Kampusch's escape, police investigated whether Přiklopil had an accomplice.<ref>* [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]], 25 August 2006. "[http://news.orf.at/060825-3165/index.html Hatte Entführer einen Komplizen?]". Accessed 25 August 2006 {{de icon}}</ref> Eventually, it was determined Přiklopil acted alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130415-kampusch-kidnapper-acted-alone-fbi-inquiry-priklopil-austria/|title=Europe – Kampusch kidnapper acted alone, probe finds – France 24|work=France 24}}</ref>
In the documentary, "Natascha Kampusch: 3096 days in captivity", Kampusch sympathised with her captor. She said "I feel more and more sorry for him—he's a poor soul", in spite of the fact that he held her captive for eight years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6958733.stm |title=Ex-kidnap girl attracts media glare |publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=23 August 2007|accessdate=23 August 2007 | first=Tristana | last=Moore}}</ref> According to police she "cried inconsolably" when she was told he was dead,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14497151/ |title=Kidnapped girl weeps for dead 'master' – World news – Europe |publisher=MSNBC |date=26 August 2006 |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> and lit a candle for him at the morgue.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5327772.stm |title=Natascha abductor buried secretly |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=8 September 2006|accessdate=23 August 2007}}</ref> She has, however, referred to her captor as a "criminal".<ref>{{cite news|first= Kate|last=Connolly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/07/wnatascha07.xml|title=Kidnapped Austrian Teenager Thought ‘Only of Escape' |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 September 2006|accessdate=7 September 2006 | location=London}}</ref>
Newspapers quoting unnamed psychologists suggested Kampusch may suffer from [[Stockholm syndrome]],<!-- a new so called Vienna syndrome, see also:http://www.zeit.de/2006/39/Titel-Richter-39?page=all --><ref>{{cite news|url=http://a.abcnews.com/GMA/story?id=2379231&page=1 |title=Escaped Austrian Teen May Have Stockholm Syndrome |publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=31 August 2006|accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5280472.stm |title=Austrian girl 'found' after years |publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=24 August 2006 |accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref> but Kampusch, in her book ''3096 Tage'' (''3,096 Days'') says this is not the case. She suggests that people who use this term about her are disrespectful of her and do not allow her the right to describe and analyse the complex relationship she had with her kidnapper in her own words.
In 2009, Kampusch became the new face of [[animal rights]] group [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] in Austria. In June, Kampusch wrote to [[Ilse Aigner]], agriculture minister in Germany where the campaign is based, demanding freedom for zoo animals, stating: "The animals would, if they could, flee as I did, because a life in captivity is a life full of deprivation. It is up to you whether social, intelligent and wonderful creatures are to be freed from their chains and cages where ruthless people keep them."<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1194077/Cellar-victim-Natascha-Kampusch-strip-animal-rights.html Cellar victim Natascha Kampusch may strip for animal rights], [[Daily Mail]], 19 June 2009</ref>
In January 2009, Vienna's public prosecutor stated that DNA tests and questioning of witnesses had led to theories being discounted that Přiklopil had an accomplice. Kampusch has also maintained that her captor acted alone.<ref>BBC News, 8 January 2010.</ref>
=== Interviews === After reportedly "hundreds of requests for an interview" with the teenager, "with media outlets offering vast sums of money", Kampusch was interviewed by Austrian public broadcaster [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]]. The interview was broadcast on 6 September 2006 with her approval.<!-- Wednesday, 18:15 (UTC) and a copy by RTL Television: 19:15 (UTC) --> ORF did not pay for its interview,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5313762.stm|title=Kidnap girl to give TV interview |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=4 September 2006|accessdate=4 September 2006}}</ref> and said any proceeds from selling the interview to other channels would be forwarded to Kampusch. The interview was sold to more than 120 countries at a fee of 290 euros per minute. This money, estimated to some hundred thousand euros,<ref> http://www.extradienst.at/jaos/page/main_heute.tmpl?article_id=18721&offset=0</ref> was to be donated to women in Africa and Mexico by Kampusch. Likewise she was planning projects to help these women.<ref>''Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung'': Natascha Kampusch - the interview, 7 September 2006</ref> Interest was enormous.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/media/article1446532.ece|title=Natascha Kampusch: 400 interview requests — that was just the start|work=The Independent|date=11 September 2006|accessdate=11 September 2006|location=London|first=Alexandra|last=Buxton|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008134748/http://news.independent.co.uk/media/article1446532.ece|archivedate=8 October 2006}}</ref>
The newspaper ''[[Kronen Zeitung]]'' and news magazine ''[[NEWS (Austrian magazine)|NEWS]]'' also interviewed Kampusch. The interview was published on 6 September 2006. Both press interviews were given in return for a package including housing support, a long-term job offer, and help with her education.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://derstandard.at/?url=/?id=2574050|title=Kampusch spricht – am Boulevard|publisher=[[Der Standard|derStandard.at]] |date=6 September 2006|accessdate=8 September 2006|language=de}}</ref>
New developments<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.orf.at/video/iptvpopup.html?natascha_kampusch_interview_final_o.wmv|title=Part of an Interview with Natascha: The Kampusch Case — A Chronicle of Failure|publisher=[[ORF 2]]|date=11 February 2008|accessdate=12 February 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080214113326/http://news.orf.at/video/iptvpopup.html?natascha_kampusch_interview_final_o.wmv <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 14 February 2008|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://wien.orf.at/stories/255889|title= ORF-Interview|publisher=ORF|date=11 February 2008|accessdate=12 February 2008|language=de}}</ref> challenged the Austrian government in February 2008. Politicians of the conservative [[Austrian People's Party]] (ÖVP) threatened to break up the newly formed [[SPÖ]]–[[ÖVP]] ("red–black") coalition government in April and May 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stern.de/politik/panorama/:Ermittlungspannen-Fall-Kampusch-Regierungskrise/610685.html |title=Ermittlungspannen – Fall Kampusch führt zur Regierungskrise|publisher=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]|date=12 February 2008|accessdate=12 February 2008|language=de}}</ref> Kampusch said that she had lost confidence in Austrian justice. Revelations of mistakes in the interior ministry's investigation of her kidnapping came to light, as well as statements of a policeman which were repeatedly ignored in 1998.{{Citation needed|date=September 2014}}
On 16 June 2008, the newspaper ''[[The Times]]'' published an in-depth interview with Kampusch by Bojan Pancevski and [[Stefanie Marsh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/article4044283.ece?print=yes |title=Natascha Kampusch: from darkness to limelight |accessdate=16 June 2008 |last=Pancevski |first=Bojan |author2=Marsh, Stefanie |date=2 June 2008 |publisher=[[The Times|Times Online]] |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615175158/http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/article4044283.ece?print=yes |archivedate=15 June 2011 }}</ref>
On 17 February 2010, the British TV channel [[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]] broadcast an hour-long documentary about the case, including an exclusive interview with Kampusch: ''Natascha: the Girl in the Cellar''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Simon|first1=Jane|title=Natascha: The girl in the Cellar, FIVE, 8pm|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-previews/natascha-the-girl-in-the-cellar-five-8pm-201922|accessdate=13 March 2017|work=the Daily Mirror|publisher=MGN Limited|date=17 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Natascha: The Girl In The Cellar|url=http://www.documentarytube.com/videos/natascha-the-girl-in-the-cellar|website=DocumentaryTube|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref>
=== Books === The book ''Girl in the Cellar: the Natascha Kampusch Story''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Girl-Cellar-Natascha-Kampusch-Story/dp/0340936487 |title=Girl in the Cellar |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> by Allan Hall and Michael Leidig appeared in November 2006, written in English. Kampusch's lawyer described the book as being both speculative and premature, and therefore planned to take legal action against it.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,451732,00.html Skandal-Buch über entführte Natascha erzürnt Familie] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711143400/http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,451732,00.html |date=11 July 2007 }}, ''Der Spiegel,'' 30. November 2006. {{de icon}}</ref>
Together with two journalists, Kampusch's mother Brigitta Sirny wrote a book about the ordeal, ''Verzweifelte Jahre'' ("Desperate Years"). Kampusch appeared at the initial presentation of the book in August 2007, but did not want to be photographed or interviewed. Sirny writes that she did not have much contact with Kampusch after the escape because Kampusch was shielded from the outside world.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,499269,00.html "Natürlich verdiene ich daran"] ''Spiegel Online,'' 10 August 2007. {{de icon}}</ref>
Kampusch wrote a book about her ordeal, ''3096 Tage'' (''3,096 Days''), published in September 2010.<ref>[http://www.focus.de/panorama/welt/entfuehrungsfall-kampusch-schreibt-autobiografie_aid_522314.html Entführungsfall: Kampusch schreibt Autobiografie] {{de icon}}</ref> It was adapted into a German movie, ''[[3096]]'', in 2013.
On 12 August 2016 Natascha Kampusch released her second book titled ''10 Years of Freedom''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kampusch|first1=Natascha|title=10 Jahre Freiheit" {{!}} Natascha Kampusch|url=http://natascha-kampusch.at/das-neue-buch-von-natascha-kampusch-10-jahre-freiheit/|website=natascha-kampusch.at|accessdate=13 March 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="Saying No to defeat is the only way to survive" – Interview with Natascha Kampusch|url=http://www.moonproject.co.uk/saying-no-to-defeat-is-the-only-way-to-survive-interview-with-natascha-kampusch/|website=MoonProject|accessdate=13 March 2017|date=21 February 2017}}</ref>
=== Media endeavors === Kampusch established her own website containing personal information including pictures of herself on 5 December 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://natascha-kampusch.at/|title=Natascha Kampusch|publisher=}}</ref> She had her own talk show on the new Austria TV channel, PULS 4,<!--http://www.puls4.com--> starting on 1 June 2008<!--http://www.kurier.at/kultur/163008.php-->. The show had the working title of ''In Conversation with…Natascha Kampusch'' and eventually premiered as ''Natascha Kampusch trifft'' (''Natascha Kampusch meets...'').<ref name="tvshow">[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/programming/a81588/kidnapped-austrian-girl-to-host-own-show.html Kidnapped Austrian girl to host own show] Digital Spy, 13 December 2007</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/kultur/medien/380538/index.do |title=DiePresse.com |publisher=DiePresse.com |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> It ran for only three shows.
On 17 June 2010, German film-maker and director [[Bernd Eichinger]] announced that he was making a film based on Kampusch's captivity and wanted [[Kate Winslet]] to star in the film.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/jun/17/kate-winslet-natascha-kampusch | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Natascha Kampusch film director eyes Kate Winslet as lead | first=Xan | last=Brooks | date=17 June 2010}}</ref> Bernd Eichinger died on 24 January 2011; Kampusch attended his funeral.<ref>{{cite news|title=German filmmaker Bernd Eichinger dies at 61|work=Reuters|date=25 January 2011|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/25/us-eichinger-idUSTRE70O7W420110125|accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref>
In 2011, the Austrian film ''[[Michael (2011 Austrian film)|Michael]]'', which has a plot that resembles the Natascha Kampusch case, was released.
On 15 April 2012, a German newspaper reported that a movie based on her autobiography with the same name was to be made, featuring [[Antonia Campbell-Hughes]] as Kampusch<ref>{{cite news|title=Film review: Natascha Kampusch’s eight years in captivity – distilled into 111 minutes of cinematic brutality in 3096 Days|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=March 2015|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/film-review-natascha-kampuschs-eight-years-in-captivity--distilled-into-111-minutes-of-cinematic-brutality-in-3096-days-8517557.html}}</ref> and [[Thure Lindhardt]] as Přiklopil. The movie ''3096 Tage'' (3096 days<!--http://www.3096tage.de -->) was directed by [[Sherry Hormann]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Flower|first=Alex|title=N.Irish actress to play Natascha Kampusch in movie: report|url=http://www.zimbio.com/Natascha+Kampusch/articles/NV7dX5IdzuH/N+Irish+actress+play+Natascha+Kampusch+movie|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130210024628/http://www.zimbio.com/Natascha+Kampusch/articles/NV7dX5IdzuH/N+Irish+actress+play+Natascha+Kampusch+movie|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 February 2013|accessdate=16 December 2012|newspaper=[[Zimbio]]|date=15 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Story of kidnap victim Natascha Kampusch set to be turned into film – with unknown Irish actress in lead role|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2130980/Story-kidnap-victim-Natascha-Kampusch-set-turned-film-called-3-096--Northern-Irish-actress-Antonia-Campbell-Hughes-lead-role.html|accessdate=16 December 2012|newspaper=Mail Online|date=17 April 2012|location=London}}</ref> and was released on 28 February 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Natascha Kampusch im Interview mit BILD – Zum 1. Mal spricht sie über ihre Vergewaltigung|url=http://www.bild.de/unterhaltung/leute/natascha-kampusch/im-interview-mit-bild-28580692.bild.html|accessdate=19 February 2013|newspaper=Bild.de|date=19 February 2013}}</ref>
=== House === [[File:Das Haus von Wolfgang Priklopil.jpg|thumb|Wolfgang Přiklopil's house in [[Strasshof]]]] The house where Kampusch was imprisoned was built by Přiklopil's grandfather, Oskar Přiklopil, after [[World War II]].<ref name="GUARD1206"/> During the [[Cold War]] period, Oskar and his son Karl built a [[Air-raid shelter|bomb shelter]], thought to be the origin of Kampusch's dungeon. Přiklopil took over the house in 1984 following his grandmother's death.
Kampusch now owns the house in which she was imprisoned, saying, "I know it's grotesque – I must now pay for electricity, water and taxes on a house I never wanted to live in". It was reported that she claimed the house from Přiklopil's estate because she wanted to protect it from vandals and being torn down; she also noted that she has visited it since her escape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30200-1316125,00.html|title=Kidnap Victim Owns Her House of Horrors|publisher=Sky News|date=15 May 2008|accessdate=15 May 2008}}</ref> When the third anniversary of her escape approached, it was revealed she had become a regular visitor at the property and was cleaning it out possibly to move in herself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.austriantimes.at/news/Panorama/2009-07-30/15162/Kampusch_to_auction_off_horror_house_items |title=Kampusch to auction off horror house items – Panorama – Austrian Times |work= |accessdate=15 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688Ynv8tb?url=http://www.austriantimes.at/news/Panorama/2009-07-30/15162/Kampusch_to_auction_off_horror_house_items |archivedate=3 June 2012 }}</ref>
In January 2010, Kampusch said she had retained the house because it was such a big part of her formative years, also stating that she would fill in the cellar if it is ever sold, adamant that it will never become a macabre museum to her lost adolescence.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1245899/Natascha-Kampusch-If-I-sell-house-I-held-captive-half-years-I-make-sure-cellar-filled-in.html Natascha Kampusch: He put me inside the cellar for eight-and-a-half years, preserved alive like an Egyptian pharaoh], ''Daily Mail''. Retrieved 26 January 2010.</ref> The cellar was indeed filled in, though Kampusch still owns the house.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QAxRCnoa9Aw Abductee Natascha Kampusch speaks out about her 8 years in captivity], YouTube</ref>
==See also== * [[Fritzl case]] * [[Jaycee Dugard]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}} <!--please integrate into the body of the article, in ref format Thanks.--> <!-- (source: German television RTL: it is own hand-writing by himself, by secret photos of the so called letter by RTL,two days ago, see also: http://derstandard.at: "Zu dem vor einigen Tagen verlesenen Brief des Entführungsopfers bekräftigte Friedrich, dass es sich bei dem im Fernsehen gezeigten Schriftstück um eine Abschrift jener "Ideen und Gedanken" von Natascha Kampusch handelte – und nicht um das Original: "Das waren einzelne Zetteln, die ich in einem Tresor aufbewahre", so der Psychiater". --The so called letter is a fake, a so called "half fake", Kampusch Brief ist eine Zusammenfassung: "Das waren einzelne Zetteln, die ich in einem Tresor aufbewahre", so der Psychiater. Er habe den Text eins zu eins übertragen, lediglich die Reihenfolge der Textpassagen sei – in Absprache mit Kampusch – verändert worden. (APA)" -->
==Further reading== * Natascha Kampusch, ''3,096 Days'', (Penguin, 2010) {{ISBN|978-0-670-91999-4}}. * Allan Hall and Michael Leidig, ''The Girl in the Cellar'', (Hodder, 2009) {{ISBN|978-0-340-99787-1}}. * Natascha Kampusch, mit Corinna Milborn und Heike Gronemeier: ''3096 Tage''. List, Berlin 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-471-35040-9}}. * Pelu, Martin: ''Der Fall Natascha Kampusch''. Tectum, Marburg 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-8288-2294-8}}; 2013 auch als E-Book, {{ISBN|978-3-8288-5608-0}}. * [[Kathrin Röggla]]: ''Die Beteiligten'', Theaterstück, 2009<ref>Ulrike Gondorf: ''[http://www.dradio.de/dkultur/sendungen/fazit/951681/ Der Fall Kampusch auf der Bühne.]'' In: ''[[Deutschlandradio Kultur]]'' vom 19. April 2009.</ref> * Sirny-Kampusch, Brigitta: ''Verzweifelte Jahre, ein Leben ohne Natascha''. Aufgezeichnet von Andrea Fehringer und Thomas Köpf, Ueberreuter, Wien 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-8000-7295-8}}.
== External links == {{Wikinews|Austrian teenager mourns captor's suicide}} * [http://www.natascha-kampusch.at Natascha Kampusch's Official Homepage] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/28/world/europe/28iht-web.0828aletter.2617398.html English translation by [[International Herald Tribune]] of open letter released by Kampusch on 28 August 2006] * [http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung.php?schluessel=OTS_20060824_OTS0216 Diagram and pictures of the hidden room] by Federal Criminal Police Office of Austria
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=May 2016}} A '''necronym''' (from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] words νεκρός, ''nekros'', "dead" and ὄνομα ''ónoma'', "name") is a reference to, or [[name]] of, a person who has [[death|died]]. Many [[culture]]s have [[taboo]]s and [[tradition]]s associated with referring to such a person. These vary from the extreme of never again speaking the person's real name, often using some [[wikt:circumlocution|circumlocution]] instead, to the opposite extreme of commemorating it incessantly by naming other things or people after the deceased.
For instance, in some cultures it is common for a newborn child to receive the name (a necronym) of a [[family|relative]] who has recently died, while in others to reuse such a name would be considered extremely inappropriate or even forbidden. While this varies from culture to culture, the use of necronyms is quite common.
==Examples== Composer [[Ludwig van Beethoven]], born in 1770, had a brother named Ludwig Maria who was born in 1769 and lived for only six days. [[Vincent van Gogh]] had a brother of the same name who was born, and died, on March 30, 1852, exactly one year before the painter's birth. The artist [[Salvador Dalí]] was born nine months and ten days after his brother, also named Salvador, died from gastroenteritis at the age of one year and nine months.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Believer - What's in a Necronym?|url = http://www.believermag.com/issues/201508/?read=article_vanasco|website = The Believer|date = 2015-08-01|accessdate = 2016-01-03}}</ref>
In [[Ashkenazi Jew]]ish culture, it is a custom to name a child after a beloved relative who died as a way of honoring the deceased. Often the child will share the same [[Hebrew name]] as the namesake but not the given name in the vernacular language (e.g. English).
In [[Culture of Japan|Japan]], [[Buddhist]] families usually obtain a necronym, called a ''[[Dharma name|kaimyō]]'', for a deceased relative from a Buddhist priest in exchange for a donation to the temple. Traditionally, the deceased were thereafter referred to by the necronym, as a sign of pious respect. This name was often the only one inscribed on [[gravestone]]s in the past, though now it is more common to have the necronym in addition to the given name.
Necronyms were also commonly used during the [[Cold War]] as a means of protecting an [[intelligence officer]]'s true identity. For example, the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[KGB]] agent [[Konon Molody]] was only known as Gordon Lonsdale (the true Lonsdale was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] born two years after Molody and died in 1943 when he was 19) in the United States. Molody adopted the name when he was 32, 11 years after the real Lonsdale's death.
==Historiography== The practice of bestowing necronyms has sometimes caused confusion for [[historian]]s. This is primarily because of the two birth certificates or records that could be present at a given time. This confusion often stems from the inability to differentiate the records of each child. One such example is the case of [[Shigechiyo Izumi]] (1865?–1986), accepted in 1986 as the world's oldest man by ''[[Guinness World Records|The Guinness Book of World Records]]'', but who was in fact possibly born in 1880, after one previous brother whose name he assumed upon his death.
==See also== *[[Posthumous name]] *[http://www.believermag.com/issues/201508/?read=article_vanasco What's in a Necronym?]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Death}} {{Personal names}}
[[Category:Cultural aspects of death]] [[Category:Human names]]

'''Nunong Karugtong''' was the name of a legendary figure<ref name="infantagov">{{Cite web|url=http://www.infanta.gov.ph/?q=mythical-origin|title=Mythical Origin {{!}} www.infanta.gov.ph|last=|first=|date=|website=www.infanta.gov.ph|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507213552/http://www.infanta.gov.ph/?q=mythical-origin|archive-date=7 May 2016|dead-url=No|access-date=2017-04-25}}</ref> in [[early Philippine history]] who supposedly established Binangonan de Lampon, the settlement which would eventually become the modern-day municipality of [[Infanta, Quezon]].<ref name="infantagov"/><ref name="Salazar20130302">{{Cite book |url=http://www.bagongkasaysayan.org/ebook/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/2.Konklusyon_Salazar_adjusted_Marked.pdf |title=TUNDUN-PAILAH-BINWANGAN: Ang Sistemang Ilog Ilaya-Ilawud ng Katagalugan bilang Halimbawa ng Isang Proseso ng Pagkabuo ng mga Sinaunang Pamayanan ng Kapilipinuhan |last=Salazar |first=Zeus |date=2013-03-02}}</ref>
According to the legend, a group of settlers led by a figure named Nunong Karugtong crossed the Sierra Madre Mountains from somewhere in what is now Rizal Province in search of better living conditions. After examining multiple sites in what is now the Municipality of Infanta, they eventually settled on a site near the Bantilan River, where the discovery of a huge Yam root convinced them that the site was ideal for settlement. This eventually became the site of the settlement which European colonizers would call "Binangonan de Lampon," which in turn would evolve into the Municipality of Infanta.<ref name="infantagov"/>
== References == {{reflist}} {{Philippines-stub}}

revision.text:
A '''patrial name''' or '''geographical surname''' is a surname or second [[cognomen]] given to person deriving from a [[toponym]], the name for a geographical place. It was particularly common in ancient Greece and Rome.<ref>The New Century classical handbook Catherine B. Avery - 1962 "Toponyms (place names) also appear: Coriolanus, Norbanus, Sabinus, Soranus, Tusculanus.</ref> The lack of a family [[surname]] and use of a geographical cognomen as a surname may the sign of a lower class, such as courtesans when signing a contract.<ref>Molière: A Theatrical Life - Page 42 Virginia Scott - 2002 "Taviani identifies Lucrezia as a courtesan because of her name that, in the fashion of courtesans, joins a Roman first name to a geographical surname and because the contract was signed in a house owned or leased by her at a time when "</ref> With medieval writers, Christian, Jewish and Muslim, whose works circulated around many countries, geographical cognomens sometimes served to distinguish better than "son of," "ben" or "ibn."
Roman Military commanders often took a second cognomen, an [[agnomen]], recalling a victorious campaign: Africanus, Asiaticus, Macedonicus, Numantinus. These may be inherited as in the case of [[Augustus]] who inherited the cognomen Thurinus.
==Formation== Examples in formation of patrial names include:
1. definite article and noun - using a [[demonym]] (also called [[gentile name]] or [[gentilic]], from Latin ''[[nomen gentile]]'' or ''[[gentilicium]]'') * [[Athenagoras of Athens|Athenagoras the Athenian]] (''Athenagoras o Athenaios,'' Ἀθηναγόρας ὁ Ἀθηναῖος). * [[Saul of Tarsus]] "Saul the Tarsian" (''Saulos o Tarseus'', Σαῦλος [ὁ] Ταρσεύς) * [[Lucius of Cyrene|Lucius the Cyrenian]] (''Loukios o Kurenaios'' Λούκιος ὁ Κυρηναῖος) * [[Trophimus]] "called the Ephesian" (''Trofimos o Efesios'', Τρόφιμος ὁ Ἐφέσιος) * [[Ibn Muʿādh al-Jayyānī|Ibn Muadh al-Jayyani]] (989-1079) "al Jayyani", the man of [[Jaén, Spain|Jaén]] * [[Isaac Alfasi]] (1013-1103) "al Fasi", the man of [[Fez, Morocco]]
2. unclear: indefinite noun / adjectival forms * [[Mary Magdalene]], "Mary of [[Magdala]]" (Greek ''Maria Magadelene,'' Μαρία Μαγδαληνή).
3. adjectives - a common Latin method for making a [[toponym]]ic adjective is to add -[i]ensis * [[Giraldus Cambrensis]] "Gerald of [[Wales]]" * [[Galfridus Monemutensis]], "Geoffrey of [[Monmouth]]"
4. genitive "of" constructions * [[Jacopo da Bologna]] "Jacob of [[Bologna]]" * [[Jacques de Vitry]] "James of [[Vitry-sur-Seine]]"
In examples 1 through 3, where the noun or adjective has case [[declension]] the partial name will typically decline in accordance with normal noun or adjective rules. For example, in ''Giraldi Cambrensis opera'' - "the works of [genitive] Gerald of Wales" - ''Giraldus'' declines to ''Giraldi'' (the genitive form of Gerald) and ''cambrensis'' (nominative adjective) declines to ''cambrensis'' (genitive adjective, but the same as nominative in this example). The declension is normally not followed when citing Latin patrial names in English, "of Giraldus Cambrensis," but may cause confusion when trying to identify the nominative spellings of patrial names from Latin or Greek sources.
==Modern era examples== Modern era examples in Europe are generally limited to nicknames, or deliberate choices of a birthplace as a penname or stagename or change of name by deed poll: * [[Bela Lugosi]] stagename "from [[Lugoj]]"<ref>Transylvania: Birthplace of Vampires - Page 32 Robert Z. Cohen - 2011 This onscreen Dracula was the creation of Transylvanian-Hungarian actor Bela Lugosi. Born Béla Blaskó in the western Transylvanian city of Lugoj (his stage name means “from Lugoj” in Hungarian</ref> * [[George Brassaï]] pseudonym "from [[Braşov]]"<ref>European culture: a contemporary companion Jonathan Law - 1993 "His professional name means 'from Brasso', his birthplace. After studying in Budapest and Berlin he moved to Paris in 1924, where he worked as a journalist; he did not take his first photograph until the age of 30.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Personal names}} [[Category:Human names]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} [[File:PayPal_Mafia.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Members of the PayPal Mafia on ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine dressed in mafia-like attire. From left to right, top to bottom: Jawed Karim, Jeremy Stoppelman, Andrew McCormack, Premal Shah, Luke Nosek, Ken Howery, David Sacks, Peter Thiel, Keith Rabois, Reid Hoffman, Max Levchin, Roelof Botha, Russel Simmons]]
"'''PayPal Mafia'''" is a group of former [[PayPal]] employees and founders who have since founded and developed additional technology companies<ref>{{cite web | url=http://projects.wsj.com/soty/mentor/david-sacks/david-sacks-drills-into-light-points-technology | title=David Sacks: Biography | publisher=Wall Street Journal online | accessdate=August 30, 2013 | author=Staff Writer}}</ref> such as [[Tesla Motors]], [[LinkedIn]], [[Palantir Technologies]], [[SpaceX]], [[YouTube]], [[Yelp]], and [[Yammer]].<ref>{{cite news|work=San Jose Mercury News|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business-headlines/ci_13617121|title=PayPal finally poised to enter Web 2.0|author=Duke Harris|date=October 22, 2009}}</ref> Most of the members attended [[Stanford University]] or [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]] at some point in their studies. Six members, [[Peter Thiel]], [[Elon Musk]], [[Reid Hoffman]], [[Luke Nosek]], [[Ken Howery]], and [[Keith Rabois]], have become billionaires.
==History== Originally, PayPal was a money-transfer service offered by a company called [[Confinity]] which was acquired by [[X.com]] in 1999. Later X.com was renamed PayPal and purchased by [[eBay]] in 2002.<ref name=pays/><ref name=fortune>{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/11/13/magazines/fortune/paypal_mafia.fortune/index.htm | title=Meet the PayPal mafia | date=November 26, 2007 | last=O'Brien | first=Jeffrey M. | accessdate=December 4, 2009 | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | publisher=CNN.com}}</ref> The original PayPal employees had difficulty adjusting to eBay's more traditional corporate culture and within four years all but 12 of the first 50 employees had left.<ref name=exodus/> They remained connected as social and business acquaintances,<ref name=exodus/> and a number of them worked together to form new companies in subsequent years. This group of PayPal alumni became so prolific that the term PayPal Mafia was coined.<ref name=pays>{{Cite news|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/17/technology/17paypal.html?ei=5088&en=943bf3f552d09fb2&ex=1318737600&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&pagewanted=all|title=It Pays to Have Pals in Silicon Valley |author=Miguel Helft|date=October 17, 2006}}</ref> The term<ref name=fortune/><ref>{{cite news|work=Fortune|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/index.cfm?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=71077|title=Thiel, Levchin and the PayPal Mafia|date=November 15, 2007}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> gained even wider exposure when a 2007 article in ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine used the phrase in its headline and featured a photo of former PayPal employees in gangster attire.<ref name=fortune/><ref name=vw1/><ref name=vw2/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Valleywag|url=http://valleywag.gawker.com/315670/the-paypal-mafia-personified|title=The Paypal Mafia Personified|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090705143412/http://valleywag.gawker.com/315670/the-paypal-mafia-personified|archivedate=July 5, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Legacy== The PayPal Mafia is sometimes credited with inspiring the re-emergence of consumer-focused Internet companies after the [[dot-com bust]] of 2001.<ref>{{cite news|work=San Francisco Chronicle|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/05/15/DDOH107DLG.DTL|date=May 16, 2008|title=Nonfiction review: 'Once You're Lucky'|author=Marcus Banks}}</ref> The PayPal Mafia phenomenon has been compared to the founding of [[Intel]] in the late 1960s by engineers who had earlier founded [[Fairchild Semiconductor]] after leaving [[Shockley Semiconductor]].<ref name=pays/> They are discussed in journalist [[Sarah Lacy]]'s book ''Once You're Lucky, Twice You're Good.'' According to Lacy, the selection process and technical learning at PayPal played a role, but the main factor behind their future success was the confidence they gained there. Their success has been attributed to their youth; the physical, cultural, and economic infrastructure of [[Silicon Valley]]; and the diversity of their skill-sets.<ref name=pays/> PayPal's founders encouraged tight social bonds among its employees, and many of them continued to trust and support one another after leaving PayPal.<ref name=pays/> An intensely competitive environment and a shared struggle to keep the company solvent despite many setbacks also contributed to a strong and lasting camaraderie amongst former employees.<ref name=pays/><ref>{{cite news|work=Wired|title=How PayPal Gave Rise to a Silicon Valley ‘Mafia’|author=Dylan Tweney|date=November 15, 2007|url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2007/11/how-paypal-gave/}}</ref>
==Members== Individuals whom the media refers to as members of the PayPal Mafia include: * [[Peter Thiel]], PayPal founder and former chief executive officer who is sometimes referred to as the "don" of the PayPal Mafia<ref name=exodus/> * [[Max Levchin]], Founder and [[chief technology officer]] at PayPal sometimes called the "[[consigliere]]" of the PayPal Mafia<ref name="fortune" /><ref name=Consigliere>{{cite news|last=O'Brien|first=Jeffrey M.|title=Meet the PayPal mafia|url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/11/13/magazines/fortune/paypal_mafia.fortune/|accessdate=August 13, 2013|newspaper=CNN Money|date=November 26, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829173209/http://money.cnn.com/2007/11/13/magazines/fortune/paypal_mafia.fortune/|archivedate=August 29, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Elon Musk]], is founder of X.com which acquired the company [[Confinity]]. Musk later co-founded [[Tesla Motors]], [[SpaceX]], [[OpenAI]], [[The Boring Company]], and is the Chairman of [[SolarCity]]<ref name=pays/><ref name=vw2>{{cite news|publisher=Valleywag|title=Why Elon Musk isn't in Fortune's PayPal Mafia picture|url=http://valleywag.gawker.com/323910/why-elon-musk-isnt-in-fortunes-paypal-mafia-picture|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124153616/http://valleywag.gawker.com/323910/why-elon-musk-isnt-in-fortunes-paypal-mafia-picture|archive-date=2009-01-24|accessdate=July 16, 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='PayPal Mafia' Gets Richer: Yelp and Facebook's IPOs will give another boost to Silicon Valley's influential PayPal alumni|author=Ari Levy|work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek|url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/paypal-mafia-gets-richer-02212012.html|date=February 21, 2012}}</ref> * [[David O. Sacks]], former PayPal COO who later founded [[Geni.com]] and [[Yammer]]<ref name=pays/> * [[Scott Banister]], former [[Ironport]] CTO and PayPal board member<ref>{{cite news|publisher=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/02/business/dealbook/the-paypal-mafias-golden-touch.html|date=April 2, 2015|author=David Gelles|title=The PayPal Mafia’s Golden Touch}}</ref> * [[Roelof Botha]], former PayPal CFO who later became a partner of venture capital firm [[Sequoia Capital]]<ref name=PayPalMafia/> * [[Steve Chen (YouTube)|Steve Chen]], former PayPal engineer who co-founded [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.biography.com/people/steve-chen-201191 |title=Steve Chen Biography |publisher=A&E Television Networks |date=April 2, 2014 |accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> * [[David Gausebeck]], former PayPal Technical Architect, co-creator of the Gausebeck-Levchin test, co-founder of Matterport Inc., a digital 3-D modeling company. <ref>matterport.com</ref> * [[Reid Hoffman]], former executive vice president who later founded [[LinkedIn]] and was an early investor in [[Facebook]], [[Aviary (application suite)|Aviary]],<ref>{{cite news|work=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jjcolao/2012/03/02/aviary-is-quietly-cornering-a-billion-dollar-market/|date=March 2, 2012|title=Aviary is Quietly Cornering a Billion-Dollar Market|author=J.J. Colao}}</ref> Friendster, [[Six Apart]], [[Zynga]], IronPort, [[Flickr]], [[Digg]], [[Grockit]], [[Ping.fm]], [[Nanosolar]], Care.com, [[Knewton]], [[Kongregate]], [[Last.fm]], [[Ning (website)|Ning]], and [[Technorati]]<ref name=pays/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tagged.com/about/press/management.html |title=Tagged.com |publisher=Tagged.com |date= |accessdate=August 31, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Greylock raises $575M fund, adds LinkedIn's Hoffman as partner|author=Scott Duke Harris|work=San Jose Mercury News|date=November 2, 2009|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_13695888}}</ref> * [[Ken Howery]], former PayPal CFO who became a partner at [[Founders Fund]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foundersfund.com/team/ken-howery |title=Ken Howery « Founders Fund |publisher=Foundersfund.com |date= |accessdate=August 31, 2013}}</ref> * [[Chad Hurley]], former PayPal web designer who co-founded YouTube<ref name=vw2/> * [[Eric M. Jackson]], who wrote the book ''[[The PayPal Wars]]'' and became chief executive officer of [[WND Books]] and co-founded [[CapLinked]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://secure.caplinked.com/users/eric-jackson |title=Secure.caplinked.com |publisher=Secure.caplinked.com |date= |accessdate=August 31, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110708115032/https://secure.caplinked.com/users/eric-jackson |archivedate=July 8, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Jawed Karim]], former PayPal engineer who co-founded YouTube.<ref name=PayPalMafia/> * Rod D. Martin, former special counsel to CEO Peter Thiel whose 10X Capital took over Galectin Therapeutics in 2009 and who founded Advanced Search Laboratories in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Rod Martin to Speak at 2015 Commencement|url=http://www.hlg.edu/newsinfo/news-story.php?id=1426/|publisher=Hannibal LaGrange University|accessdate=13 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117162021/http://www.hlg.edu/newsinfo/news-story.php?id=1426%2F|archivedate=January 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Dave McClure]], a former PayPal marketing director, a [[super angel]] investor for start up companies<ref>{{cite web|publisher=BusinessInsider|title=Where Are They Now? The PayPal "Mafia" Is More Powerful Than Ever|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-paypal-mafia-is-even-more-powerful-2011-11#dave-mcclure-has-come-into-prominence-as-one-of-the-valleys-most-active-and-vocal-angels-10}}</ref> and founder of [[500 Startups]] which has hit 500+ investments. <ref>{{cite web|publisher=BusinessInsider|title=Dave McClure Hits 500|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2013/06/27/dave-mcclure-hits-500/}}</ref> * Andrew McCormack, co-founder of Valar Ventures <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.valar.com/about |title=Andrew McCormack Partner |publisher=Valar.com |date= |accessdate=September 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923090959/http://www.valar.com/about |archivedate=September 23, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=PayPalMafia>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/11106473/The-PayPal-Mafia-Who-are-they-and-where-are-Silicon-Valleys-richest-group-of-men-now.html|title = The PayPal Mafia: Who are they and where are Silicon Valley's richest group of men now?|publisher = [[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate = 2014-09-23}}</ref> * [[Luke Nosek]], PayPal co-founder and former vice president of marketing and strategy, became a partner at [[Founders Fund]] with Peter Thiel and [[Ken Howery]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foundersfund.com/team/luke-nosek |title=Luke Nosek « Founders Fund |publisher=Foundersfund.com |date= |accessdate=August 31, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130916210808/http://www.foundersfund.com/team/luke-nosek |archivedate=September 16, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Jason Portnoy]], former vice president of financial planning and analysis who later became CFO at Peter Thiel's [[Clarium Capital]], CFO at [[Palantir Technologies]], and founding partner at Subtraction Capital. * [[Keith Rabois]], a former executive at PayPal who later worked at LinkedIn, Slide, Square, and currently Khosla Ventures, and personally invested in Tokbox, Xoom, Slide, LinkedIn, Geni, Room 9 Entertainment, YouTube, and Yelp.<ref name=PayPalMafia/> * [[Jack Selby]], former vice president of corporate and international development at PayPal who co-founded Clarium Capital with Peter Thiel, later becoming managing director of Grandmaster Capital Management.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Valleywag|url=http://valleywag.gawker.com/exposed-a-paypal-mafioso-is-behind-tips-for-jesus-mo-1476374623|title=Revealed: A PayPal Mafioso Is Behind "Tips For Jesus" Giving Spree|author=Sam Biddle|date=December 4, 2013}}</ref> * [[Premal Shah]], former product manager at PayPal, became the founding president of [[Kiva.org]].<ref name=fortune/> * [[Russel Simmons]], former PayPal engineer who co-founded [[Yelp Inc.]]<ref name=PayPalMafia/> * [[Jeremy Stoppelman]], former vice president of technology at PayPal who later co-founded Yelp, Inc.<ref name=pays/><ref name=exodus>{{cite news|work=Fortune|url=https://www.forbes.com/2006/07/12/paypal-ebay-youtube_cx_rr_0712paypal.html|title=The PayPal Exodus|author=Rachel Rosmarin|date=July 12, 2006}}</ref><ref name=vw1>{{cite web|publisher=ValleyWag|url=http://valleywag.gawker.com/315778/more-paypal-mafia-mugshots|title=More PayPal Mafia Mugshots|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100218042004/http://valleywag.gawker.com/315778/more-paypal-mafia-mugshots|archivedate=February 18, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=The New York Times|title=The Coffee Was Lousy. The Wait Was Long. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/21/business/smallbusiness/21yelp.html|author=Dan Fost|date=May 21, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek|url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/apr2008/tc2008046_819238.htm|date=April 7, 2008|title=Something to Yelp About|author=Sarah Lacy}}</ref> * [[Yishan Wong]], a former engineering manager at PayPal, later worked at Facebook and became the CEO of [[Reddit]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Quora|title=How did Yishan Wong get recruited to PayPal?|url=http://www.quora.com/How-did-Yishan-Wong-get-recruited-to-PayPal}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Traitorous eight]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|date=June 2012}} {{essay|date=June 2010}} }} A '''real-name system''' is a system in which when a user who wants to register an account on a [[blog]], website or [[bulletin board system]], is required to offer [[Identity document|identification credentials]] including their legal name to the network service centre. One may use an on-line [[pseudonym]], however, the person's real identity would be available if rules or laws are broken. ==Practice== ===South Korea=== [[South Korea]] is the first country to put the real-name system into practice. Since June 28, 2009, thirty-five Korean websites have implemented a name-registration system pursuant to the newly amended Information and Communications Network Act of Korea. It was enacted after the suicide of [[Choi Jin-sil]] which was said to be related to malicious comments about her on Internet bulletin boards. The new rule is aimed at minimizing the amount of negative information to make [[netizen]]s responsible for their behavior on the [[Internet]]. South Koreans have been familiar with the real-name system. Since the mid-1990s, doing real property transactions and financial transactions must be performed under a real name following relevant laws. The real-name system in real property transactions and financial transactions is believed to contribute to the sound economic order of the nation.''See'' the [http://koreanlii.or.kr/w/index.php/Real_name_system real name system] in Korea. On August 23, 2012, however, the [[Constitutional Court of Korea]] ruled unanimously that the real-name requirements imposed on big portal service providers by a relevant law''See'' [http://koreanlii.or.kr/w/index.php/Real_name_system Korean Legal Information Institute] for further information of the Act. is unconstitutional, citing such provision's violation of freedom of speech in cyberspace.Korea Times, "[http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2012/08/117_118115.html Online real-name system unconstitutional]", August 23, 2012. As a result, the so-called "Choi Jin-sil Law", under the deceased celebrity's name, is to be discarded. Until then, websites with more than 100 thousand visitors per day required users to authenticate their identities by entering their ID numbers when they used portals or other sites. The Constitutional Court said,
The system does not seem to have been beneficial to the public. Despite the enforcement of the system, the number of illegal or malicious postings online has not decreased. Instead, users moved to foreign Websites and the system became discriminatory against domestic operators. It also prevented foreigners who didn’t have a resident registration number here from expressing their opinions online.The Constitutional Court Decision 2010Hun-Ma47 delivered on August 23, 2012.
According to [[Yonhap News Agency]], the public voice started to agree on the abolishment of a name-registration system because of the severe problem caused by information leakage. Now the official response from the administration is that they will supplement the certain regulations of personal information on the Internet. ===China=== The Chinese government stated in December 2011 that microblogging sites should make sure users are registered with their real names.{{cite news|title=China moves to tame microbloggers amid censorship claims|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-microblogging/china-moves-to-tame-microbloggers-amid-censorship-claims-idUSBRE84S03T20120529|agency=Reuters|date=29 May 2012}} After the announcement of Regulations on the Development and Management of microblogging, Beijing in December 2011, the major microblogging sites like Sina, 163 and Sohu all put real name system into practice in 16 March 2012. The users in Beijing who hadn't provided their real information would be barred from posting and transmitting messages after 16 March 2012.{{cn|date=November 2018}}{{update inline|date=November 2018}} ==History== The introduction to real names in modern society originated from state regulations. State governments, in order to monitor and keep track of its citizens, provided citizens with surnames. This allowed them to track property ownership and inheritance, collect taxes, maintain court records, perform police work, conscript soldiers, and control epidemics.Scott, James. (1998). Seeing Like a State: How Certain Schemes to Improve the Human Condition Have Failed. ==Social networking sites== ===Facebook=== {{see also|Facebook real-name policy controversy}} Though the [[Facebook]] [[social networking site]] does not directly employ the real-name system, the site's online Name Policy indicates the following: "Facebook is a community where people use their real identities. We require everyone to provide their real names, so you always know who you're connecting with. This helps keep our community safe."{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/help/292517374180078|title=Facebook's Name Policy - Facebook Help Center - Facebook|website=www.facebook.com}} This means that under Facebook's Name Policy, users are strongly encouraged to provide their real names when creating an account on Facebook. This, according to Facebook, ensures that its users remain safe by knowing who they are connecting and communicating with at all times. Facebook was first launched at [[Harvard]], where the new social networking site provided a safe, intimate alternative to the other popular social networking sites. According to [[danah boyd]], a social media scholar, "people provided their name because they saw the site as an extension of campus life." Because of this, new users adopted the norms and practices of the early adopters and began to also see Facebook as a secure and private site. Through this early adoption, today, Facebook's astronomical value stems from the quality and quantity of information it has about its users. The social networking site has become an identity service by creating a value proposition based on social norms in which users would naturally share their real names instead of feeling forced to.boyd, danah (2012). "The Politics of 'Real Names': Power, Context, and Control in Networked Publics." Communications of the ACM. Though requiring users to provide their real names such as the ones listed on credit cards, driver's licenses, and student IDs ensures safety for users, using real names could also be harmful. Emil Protalinski, technology journalist for The Next Web, states how many "Facebook users opt to use [[pseudonyms]] to hide from stalkers, abusive exes, and even governments that don't condone free speech."{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/facebook/2012/09/21/facebook-now-wants-snitch-friends-arent-using-real-name/|title=Facebook tests prompt asking you to snitch on your friends who aren't using their real name|first=Emil|last=Protalinski|date=2012-09-21|work=The Next Web}} For these specific users, using pseudonyms allows for them to still be able to connect with colleagues, friends, and family without having to entirely worry about their safety had they provided Facebook with their real names that others could find more easily. This brings up the issues of privacy for Facebook users. "People feel as though their privacy has been violated when their agency has been undermined or when information about a particular social context has been obscured in ways that subvert people's ability to make an informed decision about what to reveal." Some users may feel uncomfortable with the knowledge that their real names would be publicly displayed and choose, instead, to use a fake name that appears real to Facebook under its Name Policy. ===Twitter=== [[File:Twitter name looks great.png|thumb|right|upright=1.6|Twitter registration page saying "Name looks great" after a made-up, meaningless, and unformatted name is entered.]] Unlike Facebook, the [[Twitter]] social networking site does not require users to enter real names when creating Twitter accounts, and the site is entirely void of the real-name system. According to Twitter's former [[CEO]], [[Dick Costolo]], the social networking site does not care what a user's real name is as long as the site connects users to the information that they care about. Whether the information comes from an account with a real name or one using a pseudonym does not matter. Yet, Costolo also points out that Twitter is not necessarily in full support of the idea of users having pseudonyms; instead, Twitter is simply "wedded to people being able to use the service as they see fit."{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/2011/09/16/why-twitter-doesnt-care-what-your-real-name-is/|title=Why Twitter doesn’t care what your real name is|date=2011-09-16|work=Gigaom.com|first=Mathew|last=Ingram}} Twitter emphasizes care in its services that it provides for users rather than requiring real names. This does not mean, however, that Twitter ignores the issue regarding real identities. Regarding this matter, Twitter is able to verify accounts of prominent Twitter users such as celebrities in order to ensure identity fraud is not being committed on the social networking site. ==In fiction== [[Vernor Vinge]]'s novella ''[[True Names]]'' charts the idea of how serious knowing one's identity can be. As such it is also a part of [[cypherpunk]] culture. ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:real-name system}} [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:Human names]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Salome Sellers |image = Salome Sellers.png |caption = Photograph of Salome Sylvester Sellers, taken at age 106 in 1906. |birth_name = Salome Sylvester |birth_date = January 1, 1800 |birth_place = [[Deer Isle, Maine|Deer Isle, Massachusetts]], [[U.S]] |death_date = January 9, 1909
(aged {{Age in years and days|1800|1|1|1909|1|9}}) |death_place = [[Salome Sellers House]], [[Deer Isle, Maine]], [[U.S]] |children = 6 |parents = Edward Sylvester and Deborah Cushman |spouse = Joseph Sellers |known_for = Last known survivor from the 18th century }} '''Salome Sellers''' (''née'' '''Sylvester'''; January 1{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}, 1800 – January 9, 1909) was an American centenarian who was the last known survivor from the [[18th century]]. ==Biography== Salome Sylvester was born in [[Deer Isle, Maine]] (then part of [[Massachusetts]]), the daughter of Edward and Deborah (''née'' Cushman) Sylvester. She grew up on Deer Isle and married Joseph Sellers on 23 December 1830. The couple had six children together, Salome outliving all but her oldest son, William. She was widowed in 1865. Due to her unusually long life, Salome was often featured in local newspapers and visited by people interested in her long life, something Salome once expressed as, "I've lived too long. I'm only a curiosity now for people to come and stare at". Salome Sellers died in the same house she and her husband had built in 1830 in Deer Isle, Maine on 9 January 1909, aged 109 years, 8 days. Her house is now known as the [[Salome Sellers House]] and home to the Deer Isle-Stonington Historical Society. There has also been a book written about her life: "An Island Woman: Salome Sylvester Sellers, 1800-1909". == See also == *[[Nabi Tajima]] (1900-2018), the last known surviving person born in the [[19th century]]. *[[Emma Morano]] (1899-2017), the last known surviving person born in the 1800s. *[[Augusta Hejnek]] (1799-1908), the last known surviving person born in the 1700s. ==External links== *[https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=43897829 Salome Sylvester Sellers] on [[Find a Grave]] *[https://www.amazon.com/Island-Woman-Sylvester-Sellers-1800-1919/dp/0966518306 An Island Woman: Salome Sylvester Sellers, 1800-1909 (1998)] *[http://dis-historicalsociety.org/the-sellers-house/ Deer Isle-Stonington Historical Society: The Sellers House] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sellers, Salome}} [[Category:1800 births]] [[Category:1909 deaths]] [[Category:Oldest people]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:People from Deer Isle, Maine]] {{US-bio-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=January 2010}} [[File:Soslan.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Dancing Soslan, [[Vladikavkaz]]]] [[File:Sosruko DSC06305.JPG|thumb|Sosruko tower in [[Nalchik]]]] '''Sosruko''' or '''Sosriqwa''' ({{lang-os|Сослан}}, ''Soslan''; {{lang-kbd|Сосрыкъуэ}}, ''Sosryqwa''; {{lang-krc|Сосурукъ/Сосуркъа}}, ''Sosuruq/Sosurqa'') is a central character in many cycles of the [[Nart sagas]] of the [[Caucasus]].
Sosruko is a powerful but devious man who is the smallest of the Narts; as a character, he is sometimes cast in the light of the [[trickster]] god, comparable to the [[Scandinavia]]n [[Loki]] (who finds a closer parallel in the Nart [[Syrdon]] however), [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] [[Amirani]], or the [[Ancient Greek]] [[Prometheus]]. It is possible that at least in the latter case, Sosruku served as a direct inspiration.
In Circassian mythology, it was Nart Sosriqwe, minion of the gods and his doting mother, Lady [[Satanaya]], who stole fire from the giant.
== Etymology == The name etymologically came from Turkic languages: [[Nogai language|Nogai]] ''suslan-'' "to look menacing", ''suslä'' "menacing, gloomy" (hence {{lang-os|Soslan}}). The variants {{lang-ab|Sasərqwa}}, {{lang-ady|Саусырыкъо}} [{{ipa|saːwsərəqʷa}}], {{lang-kbd|Сосрыкъуэ}} [{{ipa|sawsərəqʷa}}], [[Ubykh language|Ubykh]]: [{{ipa|sawsərəqʷa}}], [[Digor dialect|Digor]] {{lang-os|Sosruqo, Sozyryqo, Sozuruqo}}. The name Sosruko [{{ipa|saːwsərəqʷa}}] is from [[Circassian language|Circassian]] {{ipa|sa}} "sword" + {{ipa|wa}} "hit" + {{ipa|sər}} "heat" + {{ipa|qʷa}} "son"; hence literally “The son of the fiery sword hit”.
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''Syndicate of Seven''' is the name given to the original members of the Broken Hill Mining Company formed in 1883, who lodged applications for mining leases along the Line of Lode at [[Broken Hill, New South Wales|Broken Hill]] in [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]].
The members, who all worked at the remote [[Mount Gipps Station|Mount Gipps]] [[Sheep station]], were:-
#[[George McCulloch (mine owner)|George McCulloch]] (1848 – 1907) – station manager. #[[Charles Rasp]] (1846 – 1907) – a [[boundary rider]], who was interested in [[prospecting]], recognised the importance of the site and pegged out the first mining lease. #Philip Charley (1863 – 1937) – a young man learning to be a sheep farmer, employed as a [[boundary rider]]. #David James (1854 – 1926) – a contractor employed to sink water tanks and mend fences. #James Poole (1848 – 1924) – an employee of David James. #George Urquhart (1845 – 1915) – a bookkeeper and overseer #George Lind (1861 – 1941) – a storekeeper.
[[Image:Philip Charley thumb.jpg|right|Philip Charley in 1887]]
"Each of the above seven contributing the sum of £70 each".
(Curtis 1908, and Camilleri 2006).
In September 1883 they pegged seven {{convert|40|acre|m2|sing=on}} blocks (blocks No 10–16) along the exposed lode at Broken Hill, thus securing almost the whole of the easily worked ore (Curtis, 1908).
The Syndicate of Seven was masterminded by [[George McCulloch (mine owner)|George McCulloch]] (Camilleri, p17, 2006).
The initial assay results were not encouraging and Poole, Urquhart and Lind sold their share before the boom days and flotation of Broken Hill Proprietary in 1885 (Curtis, 1908 and Camilleri, 2006). James Poole sold half his share to [[Sidney Kidman]] who went on to become a wealthy cattle baron and landowner.
==References==
*Leonard Samuel Curtis, The History of Broken Hill, Its Rise and Progress, [[Frearson's Printing House]], Adelaide, South Australia, 1908. *[[Geoffrey Blainey|Blainey, G.]] (1964) ''The Rush that never ended: A history of Australian mining'', Melbourne, Melbourne University Press, pp 142–148. *Jenny Camilleri, In The Broken Hill Paddock, printed by Openbook Australia 2006 {{ISBN|0-646-46245-8}}.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Syndicate Of Seven}} [[Category:History of New South Wales]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Australian prospectors]]
{{NewSouthWales-stub}}
